comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Gibson's was [Edit: yay!] 9 Broad Street, which means it is this corner here (only the slope of Patrick Street remains!): Streetview

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: When did Lipton's add "By Appointment"? . Before 1896, anyhow. This page has an 1896 ad with By Appontment, but also an 1893 ad without it.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Here's a large 1892 ad.. I think this would mention the royal appointment if it had happened.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: So, 1896, maybe?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: John Gibson was there in 1881 (Slater's).

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
Gibson still there in 1894!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: "On 28th February 1895, however, his greatest prize to date came to him at long last - the Royal Warrant as purveyor of tea to Her Majesty Queen Victoria." Presumably they would remove the warrant from ads and windows after the death of the Queen in 1901?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The Tyler's shop was operated by John Kennedy and his brothers, here in the 1901 census. WRONG! see below...

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: 1896 is the only year with a Monday March 2nd in the range 1895-1901.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Info on Tylers here at the National Archives, UK, including: [no title] DE 3094/561 27 May 1896 Related information: [See also DE 3094/559-560] Contents: Copy report, with associated newspaper cutting, by Walter Tyler to Leicester, of the purchase of 1 Patrick Street and 10 Broad Street, Waterford. [no title] DE 3094/562 May 1986 Contents: Cuttings from The Waterford Star [and other newspapers?] pasted onto paper bearing related financial calculations. [no title] DE 3094/563 1 June 1896 Contents: Assignment 1. Agnes Hamilton Gibson of Broad St., Waterford, widow. 2. John Tyler & Sons Of premises in Broad St., Waterford Consideration: £700

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Niall, where are you getting the Kennedy Brothers from? Were they not Broad Street in Cork? (Please excuse the dangling preposition) Or had they moved on to Cork by 1901 and I've just missed something in your comments above?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment._content: But could I get a pair of Cowboy Boots from them?

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: A wonderful photo Carol. Tylers was still in business in Waterford up until the late 70's or early 80's I believe although their premises was on the Quay. Liptons was taken over in later years by the L & N Tea Company and was still there in the early 1970's. Tylers shop on the Quay catalogue.nli.ie/Record/P_WP_2612/Image?lookfor=http://ww...

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Edward Deevy's Drapery shop on the left of the picture and there is a photo of it in the catalogue. catalogue.nli.ie/Record/P_WP_0718/Image?lookfor=http://ww...
